awd_titl_txt: CQIS: RUI: Quantum State Symmetry and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent cutting-edge and near-future quantum devices will push the boundaries of information processing in communication, computation, and measurement in ways that will probe new physical realms and enhance the foundational understanding of physics. This project studies quantum entanglement and other nonlocal properties that power the "quantum advantage" of these revolutionary technologies. The PI seeks to design useful applications for quantum computers and quantum communication networks. In addition to achieving scientific progress through new results, a major project component is scientific development of undergraduate students through participation in real research.

This project will implement a systematic framework studying local unitary and permutational symmetries of many-body states to probe multiparticle quantum entanglement and to develop applications for quantum protocols. A main tool for entanglement analysis is the use of isotropy subgroups (that is, the set of unitaries that leave a given state invariant) of the group of local operations; the isomorphism classes of these isotropy groups are entanglement invariants that can be used not only for classification, but also for designing algorithms and protocols. Methodology includes the theory of Lie groups and Lie algebras, representation theory and Schur-Weyl duality, together with the proposer's past results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum technology is rapidly developing with the growth of powerful quantum computers, ultra-secure quantum communication devices, and ultra-sensitive quantum measurement devices. Fundamental science in physics, mathematics, and computer science provides the underpinnings for the necessary engineering. The project supported by this grant has worked to better understand the entanglement of multiparticle quantum systems that lies at the heart of much of the workings of quantum devices.

Entanglement is a resource for computation, communication, and measurement protocols. But it is not a simple resource that you simply have more or less of---there are different types of entanglement that are better or worse suited for various applications. The study of entanglement types is a subtle and difficult problem, partly because the number of different entanglement types grows exponentially with the number of particles in the quantum system. 

This project has achieved results that shed light on the variety and potential uses of entanglement types in three main investigations: hypergraph states, permutation-invariant states, and generalized Werner states. The hypergraph study shows the rich structure that arises from an entanglement scheme that is built from a single simple entangling operation (the "controlled-Z gate") repeated on many overlapping subsystems. Our study of permutation-invariant states elucidates the structure of various entanglement types that have numerous applications in quantum computation. Finally, our Werner state investigation establishes a way to construct a "complete" set of basic multiparticle states characterized by an invariance property that has been used to study foundations of quantum mechanics and also in protocols in communication.

A key aspect of the projects supported by this grant is the preparation of future scientists. Undergraduate students worked as research assistants in summer sessions. Students gained skills in independent and collaborative investigation, and in written and oral presentation skills by presenting at research symposia and short talks at scientific conferences.
